node.display_long_description:
Enjoy VR like never before by having full control of your hands and fingers to interact physically with your environment and many different objects and experiences! 

Discover the unique universe of Hand Physics Lab where you will need to fulfill a variety of tasks and puzzles with nothing but your hands!

You will go through more than 80 different puzzles and experiences to unlock multiple playgrounds where you will have full freedom to draw, build and play!

From painting eggs with your fingers, building cube towers, using magnets and telekinesis, shaking hands with your clone, petting a virtual cat, and so much more!

You will definitely put your hands in action!

**Fully playable with hand tracking and/or touch controllers**

nodes.title: Update 1.1 - Accessibility
nodes.body_text:
New skins, custom finger mapping, colorblind mode and more! üòé

You don't like the skelly fingers? Good news! You can now choose between 3 different skins for your hands!

Had some issues activating hand tracking on your device? No problem it's now fully explained when you launch the game!

This update also added custom finger mapping which allows you to map certain fingers to others to help you enjoy the experience if you suffer from a hand-related disability.

Colorblind mode is also there! Every puzzle is now fully playable without the requirements to distinguish colors.

Imperial units support system has also been added in addition to the default metric system to calibrate your height and your ideal play zone.

...and a lot more improvements and bug fixes!

Enjoy!


üåü FEATURES

- üíÖ 3 Different hands/arms skins: Transparent Skin, Bones-Flesh (default) and Cartoon Skin
- üñêÔ∏è Finger Mapping Accessibility System (map any finger to any other, except thumb)
- üëÅÔ∏è Ability to manually change Display Refresh Rate (72, 80, 90)
- üé® Colorblind mode support
- üìè Option to switch between Metric or Imperial units
- üôå Start screen to explain how to activate Hand Tracking in Oculus Settings


üëç IMPROVEMENTS

- Improved Hand Physics, more responsive, more natural!
- Warning pop up to show when hand tracking is bad or out of field of view (optional)
- Telekinesis: Easier to capture objects. Aim line is showing immediately when aiming an object
- Baskull Ball: Throwing the Skull is now easier and more natural
- When resetting level, only the physical body is reset, the camera keeps the same orientation
- Faster app loading time
- Snapping is now off by default in the "Building" playground
- Improved the Main menu and Holomenu UI
- Reduced the calibration time at start
- Fixed the pixelated edges of sprites (logos, icons, etc.)
- Improved the grab pose of the balls to throw
- Improved the feeling of throwing heavy objects
- Improved arms physics when hand detached
- Performance optimization

üîß BUG FIXES

- Fixed Local Gravity puzzle where gravity source should stay at the center of the sphere
- Fixed Invisible Objects puzzle where placed objects could fall out too easily
- Fixed arm colliders not aligned correctly when hand detaches
- Fixed a bug that prevented to correctly use grab trigger with controllers on object that were not snappable

Full Changelog: Link

nodes.title: Update 1.0.2 - Super Hand Tracking
nodes.body_text:
Super Hand Tracking Mode: Activated! üòé

If you were having issues with the quality of the hand tracking and had a difficult time solving some puzzles, this update should help! :)

This improvement allows for faster movements, better gesture detection, stable hand depiction and lower latency!

You should have a much better experience even in suboptimal lighting conditions and environments!

p.s. This new feature only works with Quest 2 (hardware limitation).



üëç IMPROVEMENTS

- Added High Frequency Hand Tracking on Quest 2


Full Changelog

node.reviewDescription: Probably the most diverse application of Quest hand-tracking out right now. Tracking can be a little flimsy at times, but that's probably due to the 'physics' element, my horrifying skeleton hands, and my messy workspace. I found that stretching a large, monochromatic blanket over shelves improved tracking somewhat. After playing, I was left with a strange sense of hand-motion-sickness. There's always been a delay to hand movement (and I think it's more noticeable on the original Quest), so if the technology were to develop any further, something a bit more instantaneous would help alleviate the floppy Surgeon Simulator feel. In the end, it's great to see the project get some structure and official recognition. (It could've done without the disappointingly familiar stock music though.)

website_page_meta.description: Enjoy VR like never before by having full control of your hands and fingers to interact physically with your environment and many different objects and experiences!
